Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Fundamental Research on Titanium Drilling with Rotary Ultrasonic Machining

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This collaborative research award supports fundamental research on rotary ultrasonic machining of titanium and its alloys in order to develop an innovative and cost-effective titanium drilling process for the nation's aerospace industry. Specifically, the research will develop a physics-based predictive model for cutting forces in drilling titanium with rotary ultrasonic machining and conduct experiments to verify the model, test the hypothesis that coolant-flow direction is the determining factor for surface roughness in titanium rotary ultrasonic machining, evaluate the feasibility of using cold air as a coolant to replace cutting fluids in titanium rotary ultrasonic machining, establish the relationship between the dominating tool-wear mechanism and machining conditions, measure the cutting temperatures, and quantify the damage to machined titanium parts caused by rotary ultrasonic machining and twist drilling.

Research results will provide knowledge and understanding to meet the critical need to develop more cost-effective titanium drilling processes for the nation's aerospace industry. A globally competitive aerospace industry will contribute to the nation's economy, and airplanes with better quality and lower manufacturing cost will benefit consumers and the society. Research results will also benefit other industries where titanium is widely used. By replacing cutting fluids with cold air as a coolant, the research will have a positive impact on the environment. This collaborative research project features a unique collaboration among Kansas State University, University of Massachusetts Lowell, Argonne National Laboratory, and industry. This collaboration provides excellent synergy for project resources, ensures the relevance of the research to industry, and expedites technology commercialization. It will also positively impact engineering education at two universities, promote lifelong learning for industrial practitioners, and broaden participation of underrepresented groups in research.

ProgramReference.Text: RET SUPP-Res Exp for Tchr Supp
EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research has generated a better understanding of and knowledge about rotary ultrasonic machining (RUM) of Ti (including titanium and its alloys) in order to develop an innovative and cost-effective Ti drilling process that is of particular interest to the U.S. aerospace industry.  The outcome of this project is a more economical machining process that is more environmentally friendly (using cold air to replace cutting fluids as coolant) than currently used processes.

This project developed a better understanding of how ultrasonic vibration affects machining (grinding and drilling) processes. Results from this project show that ultrasonic vibration can decrease cutting force and surface roughness in RUM of Ti. Lower cutting force leads to lower tool wear, lower stress, and lower cutting temperature. Decreasing surface roughness results in improved hole quality. Post drilling processes, including reaming, boring, and honing, may become unnecessary.

Major research tasks completed and outcomes are: (1) developed a physics-based predictive model for cutting forces in drilling Ti with RUM (Ti RUM) and conducted experiments to verify it, (2) tested the hypothesis that coolant-flow direction is the determining factor for surface roughness in Ti RUM, (3) evaluated the feasibility of using cold air as a coolant to replace cutting fluids in Ti RUM, (4) established the relationship between the dominating tool-wear mechanism and machining conditions in Ti RUM, (5) measured the cutting temperature in Ti RUM, and (6) quantified the damage to machined Ti parts caused by RUM and twist drilling.

Based on the work supported by this grant, 19 journal papers have been published in various peer-reviewed journals.  Nine conferences paper and one book chapter have also been published. These publications have been cited more than 100 times by researchers.

Nine undergraduate students from Kansas State University have gained research experiences with REU (Research Experience for Undergraduates) supplement support. An elementary school teacher has also participated in this research project with support from an RET (Research Experience for Teachers) grant.

This project provided research assistantship support for 3 Ph.D. students. Two of them graduated with dissertations written from research conducted on this project, and one is in the third year of a doctoral program. This project also provided support to a post-doc fellow for one year and supported undergraduate and graduate students to attend seven professional conferences to present their work. In addition, this project created various collaboration opportunities with seven companies and other two universities.

 

 


Last Modified: 09/16/2015
Modified by: Bradley A Kramer
